channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: India wins the T20 World Cup, defeating South Africa for the cricket title
item.description: After a rough start, India turned the match around, winning in a nail-biter. This was India’s second T20 World Cup win; the team won the inaugural T20 World Cup in 2007.
item.content:encoded:
After a rough start, India turned the match around, winning in a nail-biter. This was India’s second T20 World Cup win; the team won the inaugural T20 World Cup in 2007.

(Image credit: Ramon Espinosa)
item.dc:creator: Mansee Khurana

item.title: Early in the hurricane season, an unusually strong storm moves through the Caribbean
item.description: Beryl strengthened from a tropical storm into a hurricane on Saturday as the storm makes its way through the southeast Caribbean. It is expected to become a major hurricane.
item.content:encoded: Beryl strengthened from a tropical storm into a hurricane on Saturday as the storm makes its way through the southeast Caribbean. It is expected to become a major hurricane.
item.dc:creator: Mansee Khurana

item.title: Should President Biden step aside in the 2024 election?
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman about why he thinks President Biden should step aside in the 2024 election.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman about why he thinks President Biden should step aside in the 2024 election.
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: The Supreme Court overruled decades of administrative law. What happens now?
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with law professor Jody Freeman about what the Supreme Court's overturning of the Chevron case means for how federal agencies can regulate.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with law professor Jody Freeman about what the Supreme Court's overturning of the Chevron case means for how federal agencies can regulate.
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: U.S. gymnastics Olympic trials take place in Minneapolis
item.description: In Minneapolis this week, the best gymnasts in the U.S. are competing to make the team that will compete at next month's Olympics in Paris. Simone Biles aims to make her third Summer Games.
item.content:encoded: In Minneapolis this week, the best gymnasts in the U.S. are competing to make the team that will compete at next month's Olympics in Paris. Simone Biles aims to make her third Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: Ahead of parliamentary elections, the French left unites against the right
item.description: A disparate group of left-wing and Green parties unites to fight France's far-right in legislative elections.
item.content:encoded: A disparate group of left-wing and Green parties unites to fight France's far-right in legislative elections.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: 'Road to Rickwood' tells the story of Alabama's famed Rickwood Field
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with journalist Alana Schreiber and comedian Roy Wood Jr. about their new podcast, "Road to Rickwood," which documents the history of Rickwood Field in Alabama.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with journalist Alana Schreiber and comedian Roy Wood Jr. about their new podcast, "Road to Rickwood," which documents the history of Rickwood Field in Alabama.
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: Kentucky judge throws out Jewish mothers' lawsuit challenging the state's abortion ban
item.description: Three Jewish women challenged Kentucky's near-total abortion ban on the grounds that it infringed on their religious beliefs that life begins at birth, not conception.
item.content:encoded:
Three Jewish women challenged Kentucky's near-total abortion ban on the grounds that it infringed on their religious beliefs that life begins at birth, not conception.

(Image credit: Timothy D. Easley)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: Orlando Cepeda, the slugging Hall of Famer nicknamed 'Baby Bull,' dies at 86
item.description: One of the first Puerto Rican stars in the majors but limited by knee issues, he became Boston’s first designated hitter and credits his time as a DH for getting him enshrined in the Hall of Fame.
item.content:encoded:
One of the first Puerto Rican stars in the majors but limited by knee issues, he became Boston’s first designated hitter and credits his time as a DH for getting him enshrined in the Hall of Fame.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Fetterman traveled to Israel and met with Netanyahu despite blowback on the left
item.description: Why Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa., visited Israel this week, and how the visit underscores tensions among Democrats over the war in Gaza.
item.content:encoded:
Why Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa., visited Israel this week, and how the visit underscores tensions among Democrats over the war in Gaza.

(Image credit: Maya Levin for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin
